linkTarget.anchoringText: Novoportovskoe field was discovered on December 24, 1964, by a gas spouter obtained from exploration well R-50 with a daily production rate of over 1 million cubic meters. Novoportovskoe oil, gas and condensate field is located in the south-east of the peninsula, 250 km north of the town of Nadym, 30km away from the coast of the Gulf of Ob on the Yamal Peninsula and belongs to West Siberian Oil and Gas Province (Fig. 1). Due to logistical, climatic and technological difficulties, a full-scale production drilling commenced only in 2014.

The Jurassic reservoir of Novoportovskoe field is represented by sandstone with interlaid lens-shaped clay bands and limestones. Yu2-6 formation is the most interesting in terms of its development in the Jurassic sequence section. The oil-saturated thickness of the horizon is 40 m (Fig. 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Typical Section of J2-3 Formation of Novoportovskoe Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Section of J2-3 Formation of Novoportovskoe Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: The first campaign in multistage hydraulic fracturing started at Novoportovskoe field in 2015. Based on the results, the problem of a breakthrough into the gas horizon as well as a significant water encroachment of the influx was clearly identified. A high gas ratio (more than 1000 m3/t while planned rate is110 m3/t) and water cut of more than 50% (Fig. 3) were received at the majority the wells treated. Such parameters clearly indicate the involvement of gas and water-bearing formations, which leads not only to the reduction of well productivity but also to an additional load onto the field infrastructure (the necessity to utilize gas and water).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Typical Section of Yu2-3 Formation of Novoportovskoe Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Section of Yu2-3 Formation of Novoportovskoe Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the results of the experiments (Fig. 4), the optimum concentration of clay stabilizer was found for the conditions of Novoportovskoe field, which allows avoiding any issues associated with the decrease of the formation porosity and permeability and, consequently, the failure to reach oil production rate after the treatment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: CST Tests on Various Process Water Sources

formatted-caption.caption-text: CST Tests on Various Process Water Sources

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this paper, we present a unique study of the rheological properties of the fluid with imitating the fluid passing through the liner assembly seats. The study data are described in Figure 5. The fluid viscosity recovery after shear loads up to 400 cP in less than 40 seconds is shown.
Figure 6 shows the destruction efficiency of the test fluid using a new enzyme breaker of the selected concentration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Tests on Fluid Destruction by enzymes

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tests on Fluid Destruction by enzymes

linkTarget.anchoringText: The data on compatibility of optimized hydraulic fracturing fluid system (destructed) with the formation oil of Novoportovskoe field (Figure 7) also showed positive results on breaking of the emulsion. A complete separation of fluid and oil was noted for all three volumetric ratios -1:3, 1:1 and 3:1 for a 5-minute time period.

The most important parameters of the hydraulic fracturing modeling and stress profiling are the rock mechanical properties of the formation such as Poisson's ratio and Young's modulus. One of the most reliable sources of Poisson's ratio and Young's modulus is the wideband sonic log (Fig. 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Example of Long-Spaced Sonic Log of Novoportovskoe Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of Long-Spaced Sonic Log of Novoportovskoe Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Sustained efforts were taken at Novoportovskoe field to select core samples of the Jurassic horizon and to study the core material. The outcome of such work became the calculation of correlation dependence, which is unique for this formation (Fig. 9):

Microseismic monitoring (MSM) was performed at eight stages of hydraulic fracturing in a typical horizontal well. Tonnage of hydraulic fracturing stages varied from 8 to 18 tons in order to compare the fracture geometry achieved with different fracture designs (Fig. 10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Seismic Events and Fracture Profiles for Hydraulic Fracturing Based on Microseismic Monitoring Results

formatted-caption.caption-text: Seismic Events and Fracture Profiles for Hydraulic Fracturing Based on Microseismic Monitoring Results

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the fracture profile in Figure 6, there is an obvious variability in the geometry from port to port. At three stages, hydraulic fracture heights greater than in the prepared design were obtained (Fig. 11). It was also noted that at some stages with an equal height in the model and microseismic monitoring, the fracture location against the wellbore was different from the hydraulic fracturing design (Fig. 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of Fracture Heights of Fracturing Model and Heights Obtained during MSM

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of Fracture Heights of Fracturing Model and Heights Obtained during MSM

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the fracture profile in Figure 6, there is an obvious variability in the geometry from port to port. At three stages, hydraulic fracture heights greater than in the prepared design were obtained (Fig. 11). It was also noted that at some stages with an equal height in the model and microseismic monitoring, the fracture location against the wellbore was different from the hydraulic fracturing design (Fig. 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Location Change of Hydraulic Fracture against Wellbore in Hydraulic Fracturing Model and during MSM

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location Change of Hydraulic Fracture against Wellbore in Hydraulic Fracturing Model and during MSM

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the MSM results, the fracture propagation along the wellbore (in accordance with the well azimuth) was also proved; such location of the fractures significantly increases the contact area of the fracture with an openhole (Fig. 13).

This study is of a particular importance to implement the hydraulic fracturing project at Novoportovskoe field, as it gives a direct assessment of barriers and obtained fixed fracture geometry. Based on the obtained data for the fracture height and using the data of the bottomhole pressure gage, the hydraulic fracturing model was calibrated (Fig. 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Calibration of Hydraulic Fracturing Model Using Cross-Dipole Acoustic Log Data

formatted-caption.caption-text: Calibration of Hydraulic Fracturing Model Using Cross-Dipole Acoustic Log Data

linkTarget.anchoringText: Production logging investigations were carried out at a series of wells. Generally, concluding from the study data analysis, the port location in a more shales interval leads to an increased risk of fracture breakthrough into gas/water-bearing intervals. It is also important to note the inevitability of fracture breakthrough into the water-bearing horizon; however, its involvement degree highly depends on the port location (Fig. 15).

As a combined effect from the performed process optimization of multistage hydraulic fracturing, a comparison of two horizontal wells with a similar geological section appears to be significant (Fig. 16): Well A was brought into production shortly before writing this article (after the process optimization); Well

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Geological model section along Well A (left) and Well Z (right)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological model section along Well A (left) and Well Z (right)

linkTarget.anchoringText: As a result of the process optimization, it became possible to place hydraulic fractures of the same size (same proppant tonnage) with a much smaller liquid volume (due to Ball Dropper technology) and gellant amount, which reduced fracture contamination, within a few months. This resulted in a sufficient increase in well productivity; the comparison of barrels of oil per day is shown in Fig. 17. Well A, where multistage hydraulic fracturing was performed without breaks and with gel loading of 2.0 kg/m3, demonstrates a significantly higher performance comparing to Well Z, where using the conventional injection technique, fracturing fluid of the previous stage had to be utilized in the fracture and the gel loading was 2.8 kg/m3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Oil rate wells A and Z.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil rate wells A and Z.
